"'Tis a token dear Colin, of love,</br>To admire my favorite spot;</br>And since so indulgent you prove,</br>Let's hasten and here raise a cot.
"Gay roses shall here show their pride,</br>There, myrtles shall bloom in a row;</br>Sweet violets I'll plant on each side,</br>Before them the primrose shall grow."
Thus Phoebe would talk for awhile,</br>To pleasure her listening swain,</br>O!  then she'd ingagingly smile,</br>And tell the dear story again.
Since now my past pleasures I've told,</br>T' my sorrows ye shepherds give ear,</br>Nor blame me while them I unfold,</br>If for Phoebe I drop the fond tear.
We'd fixt for our wedding a day,</br>Let the nymphs and the shepherds all know,</br>Before us the swains were to play,</br>While their damsels sweet flow'rs should strow.
With the lark in the morning I rose,</br>(My thoughts were too busy to rest)</br>I hasted to put on my cloaths,</br>In my holiday suit I was dress'd.
Impatient to have the dear prize,</br>O'erjoy'd to her cottage I fled;—</br>But judge ye fond youths my surprize,</br>When told my dear Phoebe was dead!
Since that I have wander'd in pain,</br>Neglecting my once tended sheep,</br>Yet, when I cross over the plain,</br>I sighing look on them, and weep.
Ye painters whose province is woe,</br>If useful to shepherds you'ld be,</br>Come paint all the torments I know,</br>That swains may hereafter be free,
To each let a picture be shown,</br>Or hung on some tree in each grove,</br>And that its intent may be known,</br>Write under "occasioned by love."</br>
